results.title: Yevtushenko: a poet's journey
results.creator_credit: Films for the Humanities and Harold Mantell
results.brief_description: On a tour of the US and at home in his Moscow appartment, Russian poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko struggles with the responsibilities traditionally contigent on his country’s writers; custodians of the public conscience and witnesses to the naked tragedy of life in a hostile physical environement and under a succession of autocratic regimes. Yevtushenko is both the gentle melancholy writer and the powerful and charismatic poet-performer; the film captures this duality in his impassioned readings of the poems ‘Babi Yar’, ‘Prologue’ and ‘Bratski Station’. A hauntingly beautiful portrait of this fine Russian poet.

results.title: Yesterday, today: the Netsilik eskimo
results.creator_credit: Marc Beaudet, ONF | NFB and Gilles Blais
results.brief_description: Until the mid-1960s Zachary Itimignac and his family lived the nomadic life of the Inuit hunter in the Pelly Bay region of the Arctic. Then the Canadian government introduced measures to provide heated dwellings, a school, a hospital, medical care, a cooperative, air transportation, etc. This film is a day-long study of the impact of the changed way of life on this one family.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Marc Beaudet, ONF | NFB and Gilles Blais

results.title: Yesterday's witness: the first boy scouts
results.creator_credit: Stephen Peet, British Broadcasting Corporation and Tim Byford
results.brief_description: Three of the Brownsea Island boys, who accompanied Baden-Powell on the first camp in 1907, recall the first days of scounting. lady Baden-Powell talks about her life with Lord Baden-Powell. Also considers the social context of scouting, and its state of development.

results.title: Yesterday's witness: a tribute to the American newsreel
results.brief_description:
A chronicle of the newsreel in America, the curious child of journalism and show business that pioneered the coverage of news on film. Format of the film is similar to a newsreel with respect to the juxtaposition of images, the raising of issues without following them through, and the shock value of pictures.
Suitable for middle and upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Yesterday
results.creator_credit: Gordon White, Gordon White and Associates and Conrad Standish
results.brief_description: A young boy of the 1670’s wanders through the Swan Hill Pioneer Settlement and views some characteristic features of life there in the past. Residents of the Settlement in period costume, an old steamboat - the Pyap - journeying down the Murray River, horse-drawn coaches, and colonial buildings, all contribute to this picture of yesterday’s Swan Hill. Accompanied by instrumental folk music.

results.title: Yes, Virginia, there is a Santa Claus
results.creator_credit: Wolper Productions, Bill Melendez, Mort Green and Tom Keegan
results.brief_description: The story of eight-year-old Virginia O’Hanlon who tries every source to find out if there really is a Santa Claus and finally writes to the editor of the New York Sun for her answer. Suitable for primary level.

results.title: Yes or no, Jean-Guy Moreau
results.creator_credit: Barrie Howells, Tina Viljoen, Judith Vecchione, ONF | NFB and Michael Rubbo
results.brief_description: Jean-Guy Moreau is a Quebecois impersonator and political satirist who rises far above the level of being merely funny. In this film he prepares to perform in English before a Toronto audience. He will impersonate Premier Rene Levesque conducting a press conference. Moreau becomes so caught up with his subject that at times his personality merges with that of Levesque, as he fends off the questions of an equally involved audience.

results.title: Yen Family = Kimura-Ke No Hitobi To
results.creator_credit: Fuji Television Productions, Melies, Shuji Miyajima, Shinya Kawai and Yojiro Takita
results.brief_description: In Japan today everyone is looking for ways to increase their wealth and assets, but the Kimura family is particularly determined - in fact it is abnormally determined - to accumulate wealth. They don’t want a palatial mansion, they have no outstanding loans and they are not planning to travel abroad. They just love money so much that they work day and night for even the smallest amounts. And of course nothing is allowed to go to waste.

results.title: Yellow trail from Texas
results.brief_description: Despite the hard work and nomadic life style of wheat harvest crews as they travel from Texas to Canada. Considers the implications of the harvest on the ecomony and nutritional health of the world.
